titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Laura Smith.

publicationstmt.publisher: Archives & Special Collections at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center, University of Connecticut Libraries

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2012-08-01T08:35-0400
profiledesc.langusage: The finding aid is written in English.

did.unittitle: Seth P. Holcombe Papers

repository.corpname: Archives & Special Collections at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center, University of Connecticut Libraries

physdesc.extent: Five boxes of photographic prints and negatives

did.abstract: The Papers consist of approximately 350 photographic prints and 500 negatives of images of steam locomotives mostly of the New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad, taken in the Hartford, Connecticut, area.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Seth Pomeroy Holcombe was born on February 15, 1918, the son of Harold Goodwin Holcombe and Ethel Monson Holcombe. He grew up in Hartford, Connecticut, one block west of the railroad station, where he would frequently visit the station master and inquire about the engines passing through. He graduated from Trinity College in 1941.

Mr. Holcombe was the Secretary and Registrar of the Morgan Horse Club, now known as the American Morgan Horse Association. He married Lucy B. Eaton on January 17, 1959, and lived in Simsbury, Connecticut, from 1959 to 1974, and then in North Granby, Connecticut, until his death. He was an active member and President of the Salmon Brook Historical Society, served on the Granby Zoning Board of Appeals and as Treasurer of the F.H. Cossitt Library, and was a member of the Granby Republican Committee. He was instrumental in organizing the Granby Horse Council. He compiled and published several family genealogies and an anthology of letters written from 1822 to 1842 by Nancy Smith Huggins Holcomb, his great-great-grandmother.

Mr. Holcombe was a member of the Hartford Railroad Enthusiasts and took photographs of steam trains of the New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad and on excursion trips of other steam railroads in the northeast United States.
Seth P. Holcombe died on July 9, 2009.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open and available for research.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Copyright Information
userestrict.p: Permission to publish from these Papers must be obtained in writing from both the University of Connecticut Libraries and the owner(s) of the copyright.

acqinfo.head: Provenance and Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Papers were donated in March 2012 by Mrs. Lucy E. Holcombe of North Granby, Connecticut.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I consists of photographic prints, organized by size and thereunder by year and month taken. Series II consists of negatives, organized by a number on the envelope applied by Mr. Holcombe as the photographer; the negative envelope number reads consecutively so that negatives are organized generally by date.

Mr. Holcombe often wrote the negative envelope number on the back of a print. Some of the prints have a description written on the back but for many of them the only way to know of the place the scene was taken or other details is to cross-reference the print to the negative envelope.
Note that many of the negatives do not have a corresponding print and many of the prints do not have a corresponding negative.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Papers consist of photographic prints and negatives, almost all taken by Seth P. Holcombe from 1946 to 1953, with some undated, mostly of locomotives of the New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad, better known as the New Haven Railroad, taken at locations in Connecticut, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, and the Maybrook, New York, railroad yard. Other locations, of photographs more likely taken in the 1950s, include locations such as Maine, New Hampshire, and Virginia.

Other railroads represented include the Boston & Maine Railroad, the Canadian National Railroad, the Central Railroad of New Jersey, the Central Vermont Railway, the Chesapeake & Ohio Railroad, the Delaware & Hudson Railroad, the Edaville Railroad, the Lehigh & Hudson River Railway,the Lehigh & New England Railroad, the Maine Central Railroad (leased by the Boston & Maine Railroad), the New York & New England Railroad (a predecessor railroad line of the New Haven Railroad), the New York Central Railroad, the Rutland Railroad, and the St. Johnsbury & Lake Champlain Railroad.

Don Ferry is identified as the photographer of photographs of the Rutland Railroad. George L. Heath is identified as the photographer of the New York Central Railroad photographs. Mr. Holcombe's mother, Ethel Monson Holcombe, is identified as the photographer of the "Ike's Train" photographs.
Unless otherwise noted all engines and trains are those of the New Haven Railroad.
Unless otherwise noted all photographs are in black & white.
There are a very small number of postcards in the collection.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Archives & Special Collections has a substantial collection of materials pertaining to New England railroads. For detailed information on these collections please contact the curator or ask at the Reading Room desk.

Engine 2446 at the East Hartford, Connecticut, roundhouse; engine 1332 at Bolton Notch, Connecticut; engines 1007, 3206, 3208, 3210, 3223, 3227, 3558 and 3562,

Engine 832 and others of the Central Railroad of New Jersey , possibly in Easton, Pennsylvania; Engine 1311 and 3208, location unknown; Engines 1000, 1001, 1341, 3210, 3221, 3219 and 3560, in Newington, Connecticut; Engine 1407 on the turntable possibly at the Maybrook, New York, railroad yard (one person identified in a print as Bob Marchant;

Engines 1311, 1312, 1349, 1380, 1387, 1388, 3233 and 3235 (with view of "Mr. Taylor," the engineer, in cab); engines 1388, 3206, 3335 (identified as the "Speed Witch") in Bolton, Connecticut; engines 1341 and 1351 in Bolton Notch, Connecticut,

Engines 1381 (identified as the "Gauset Special") and 3335 (identified as the "Speed Witch") in Bolton or Manchester, Connecticut; unidentified engines possible of the Canadian National Railroad in Amherst, Massachusetts; scenes of a railroad roundhouse in Brattleboro, Vermont,
Engines 1349 (east of Terryville, Connecticut, depot), 3011 ("backing into east end of Terryville Tunnel") and 3022,
Engines 479, 1001 supplying heat to Freedom Train, 1349 at Terryville, Connecticut, 3019 at Plainville, Connecticut, and 3013 at Holyoke, Massachusetts (very likely a train excursion),
Engines 1327 and 1331 in Newington, Connecticut; engine 1349 in East Hartford, Connecticut,
Engine 1347 in Hartford, Connecticut, and an unidentified freight train, all snow scenes,
Engines 479, 3014, 3335, and 3423; unidentified train at "Boston Roundhouse,"
Engine 1300 with train 130, east of Bolton Notch, Connecticut; engine 2446 at unidentified roundhouse,
Central Vermont Railway 472 and New Haven Railroad engine 1371 at the Willimantic, Connecticut, railroad station; engines 1327 and 1361 in Hartford, Connecticut,
Engine 1324 and the "Sphinx Special," train 1300, probably in Hartford, Connecticut, (note that the "Sphinx Special" was likely a special chartered train for a Masonic group),
Engine 3022 at the Amston, Connecticut, station,
Engine 1300 near the Walnut Street bridge in Hartford, Connecticut,

Engines 455 and 1331 at Willimantic, Connecticut; the Delaware & Hudson Railroad's Mallet freight locomotive in Mechanicsville, New York; the Boston & Maine Railroad's engine 1450 at North Station in Boston, Massachusetts,
Lehigh & Hudson River Railway engine 12 at Maybrook, New York,
Engine 1337 near Walnut Street bridge in Hartford, Connecticut; "Yard goat" engine 2353 at East Hartford, Connecticut, roundhouse,
Engine 3334 in Hartford, Connecticut,

Trains of the Edaville Railroad, in South Carver, Massachusetts,
Locomotive 93, the "Exchange Club Special," of the Rutland Railroad (note that photograph was taken by Don Ferry),
Chesapeake & Ohio Railway engine 1201 in Charlottesville, Virginia,
Engines 13 and 76 of New York Central Railroad on the Harlem Division, one of them in , photographer identified as George L. Heath,
Engine 1004 in Newport, Rhode Island; engine 1357 in Lowell, Massachusetts; engine 1387 at South Station in Boston, Massachusetts,
Engine 1388 on the New Haven Railroad's "last steam trip," at stops in Boston, Massachusetts, New London, Connecticut, and New Haven, Connecticut; photographs include many with the train's crew,
Central Vermont Railway engine 470 at Willimantic, Connecticut, Palmer, Massachusetts, and Brattleboro, Vermont; rear of New Haven Railroad Budd RDC car on exhibition (location unknown),
Maine Central Railroad/ Boston & Maine Railroad engines, including 3712, the "East Wind," at South Station in Boston, Massachusetts, station and various locations in Maine,
Boston & Maine Railroad locomotive 1441 at various locations in North Station in Boston, Massachusetts, and in New Hampshire,
Covered railroad bridge on St. Johnsbury & Lake Champlain Railroad, near Hardwick, Vermont,
Two color photographs of "Ike's Train" in Hartford, Connecticut, likely a campaign train used by Presidential candidate Dwight D. Eisenhower. Photographer identified as Seth Holcombe's mother,
Derailment of a freight car on siding just north of crossing with highway, east of Granby Center, Connecticut,
Engine 3016 at New Haven, Willimantic and New London, Connecticut,
Postcard with a drawing "The Old War Engine 'Texas,' Cyclorama Building, Grant Park, Atlanta, Georgia,"

New Haven Railroad engines, places unknown,
Rutland Railroad engines,

Large prints,

Engine 1027 in unidentified location and engine 3217 in Hartford, Connecticut,
